Lit-4.SVO_relationships:
It seems like you've provided an excerpt from a text (likely from a novel or story) and a JSON-like structure describing Subject-Verb-Object (SVO) relationships. To transform these sentences into the SVO format similar to the JSON structure you've given, here's how it might look:
SVO 1:
Subject: thefake, country-wetfreshness
Verb: evaporated
Object: likethetailendofasweetdream
Transformed SVO: The fake, country-wet freshness evaporated like the tail end of a sweet dream.
SVO 2:
Subject: thehotstreets
Verb: wavered
Object: inthesun
Transformed SVO: The hot streets wavered in the sun.
SVO 3:
Subject: I
Verb: kepthearing
Object: abouttheRosenbergsovertheradioandattheoffice
Transformed SVO: I kept hearing about the Rosenbergs over the radio and at the office.
SVO 4:
Subject: I
Verb: couldn'tget
Object: themoutofmymind
Transformed SVO: I couldn't get them out of my mind.
These transformations aim to convert each SVO relationship into a grammatically correct sentence while preserving the original meaning as closely as possible. Let me know if you need further assistance or if there's anything else you'd like to explore!

Lit-9.SVO_relationships:
Here is the transformation of the excerpt into a Subject-Verb-Object (SVO) format:
Original:
"In France the young girls have a dull time of it till they are married, when ‘Vive la liberte!’ becomes their motto. In America, as everyone knows, girls early sign the declaration of independence, and enjoy their freedom with republican zest, but the young matrons usually abdicate with the first heir to the throne and go into a seclusion almost as close as a French nunnery, though by no means as quiet. Whether they like it or not, they are virtually put upon the shelf as soon as the wedding"
Transformed:
In France, the young girls have a dull time of it until they are married. ‘Vive la liberte!’ becomes their motto. In America, as everyone knows, girls sign the declaration of independence early and enjoy their freedom with republican zest. However, the young matrons usually abdicate with the first heir to the throne and go into seclusion almost as close as a French nunnery, though not as quiet. Whether they like it or not, they are virtually put upon the shelf as soon as the wedding

Lit-10.SVO_relationships:
Here is the transformed excerpt in a Subject-Verb-Object (SVO) format:
Original:
"Entirely absorbed in her children, to the utter exclusion of everything and everybody else. Day and night she brooded over them with tireless devotion and anxiety, leaving John to the tender mercies of the help, for an Irish lady now presided over the kitchen department. Being a domestic man, John decidedly missed the wifely attentions he had been accustomed to receive, but as he adored his babies, he cheerfully relinquished his comfort for a time, supposing with masculine ignorance that peace would soon be restored. But three months passed,"
Transformed:
Entirely absorbed in her children, she brooded over them day and night with tireless devotion and anxiety, to the utter exclusion of everything and everybody else. John, being a domestic man, decidedly missed the wifely attentions he had been accustomed to receive. An Irish lady now presided over the kitchen department, leaving him to the tender mercies of the help. However, as he adored his babies, he cheerfully relinquished his comfort for a time, supposing with masculine ignorance that peace would soon be restored.

Lit-26.SVO_relationships:
Here is the transformed excerpt into a Subject-Verb-Object (SVO) format:
Original:
"There was no return of repose. Meg looked worn and nervous, the babies absorbed every minute of her time, the house was neglected, and Kitty, the cook, who took life ‘aisy’, kept him on short commons. When he went out in the morning he was bewildered by small commissions for the captive mamma, if he came gaily in at night, eager to embrace his family, he was quenched by a ‘Hush! They are just asleep after worrying all day.’ If he proposed a little amusement at home, ‘No, it would"
Transformed:
There was no return of repose. Meg looked worn and nervous. The babies absorbed every minute of her time. The house was neglected, and Kitty, the cook, who took life 'aisy', kept him on short commons. In the morning, he was bewildered by small commissions for the captive mamma. At night, when he came gaily in, eager to embrace his family, he was quenched by a 'Hush! They are just asleep after worrying all day.' If he proposed a little amusement at home, 'No, it would

They are just asleep after worrying all day.’ If he proposed a little amusement at home, ‘No, it would"
Transformed:
There was no return of repose. Meg looked worn and nervous. The babies absorbed every minute of her time. The house was neglected, and Kitty, the cook, who took life 'aisy', kept him on short commons. In the morning, he was bewildered by small commissions for the captive mamma. At night, when he came gaily in, eager to embrace his family, he was quenched by a 'Hush! They are just asleep after worrying all day.' If he proposed a little amusement at home, 'No, it would

Lit-33.SVO_relationships:
Transformed into a Subject-Verb-Object (SVO) format, the excerpt would look like this:
Original:
"‘Well I never cared for anyone but Jo,’ Laurie said that in his old, impetuous tone, and turned his face away as he spoke. ‘I did think so, but as they never said anything about it, and you came away, I supposed I was mistaken. And Jo wouldn’t be kind to you? Why, I was sure she loved you dearly. ‘She was kind, but not in the right way, and it’s lucky for her she didn’t love me, if I’m the good-for-nothing fellow you think me. It’s her fault though,"
Transformed:
Laurie said that in his old, impetuous tone, ‘Well, I never cared for anyone but Jo,’ and turned his face away as he spoke. He continued, ‘I did think so, but as they never said anything about it, and you came away, I supposed I was mistaken. And wouldn’t Jo be kind to you? Why, I was sure she loved you dearly. She was kind, but not in the right way, and it’s lucky for her she didn’t love me, if I’m the good-for-nothing fellow you think me. However, it’s her fault though,"
